Award.AwardTitle: Intervention to Improve Engagement and Mediate Conclusion Fear in Engineering Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs propose an unorthodox and transformational approach to improving engineering education.
It requires embracing a concept that has been used with great success by other organizations from marketing firms to educational television: humor. Despite the light nature of the subject, the team will conduct a large-scale controlled study to quantitatively determine if humor is statistically effective in improving engineering education. Specifically, they will test if the general intervention of humor can improve general engineering educational outcomes and retention. The hypothesis is that such an improvement would be due to an increase in the immediacy of the instructor interaction and they will test the likelihood that this mechanism is behind any observed improvement. They will also test if the use of humorous or whimsical systems with no less technical rigor (i.e. swelling gummi bears vs. heat exchangers) will reduce students? inability to make conclusions from engineering analysis (Conclusion Fear). Based on Cognitive-Affective personality theory, the team believes students? fear making conclusions given the internal impression that faculty are domain-experts that will severely criticize their conclusions. By using humorous systems for data or model analysis they will dispel this impression and empower students to make the important conclusions they need to make engineering design decisions thereby improving educational outcomes. The proposed work uses a unique team of an educational researcher experienced in engineering education and an engineering professor who is also a professional
comedian.

Intellectual Merit :
This will be the first large-scale controlled experiment to determine the effectiveness of
humor on technical education, amid a sea of action-research investigations that have little
or no statistically significant results. This study will also provide insight into the mechanism
behind the effectiveness of a humorous intervention based on current personality theories.
Such insight will allow more general application of humor to improve engineering education.

Broader Impacts :
The results of this study will have significant impact on (i) distance learning (the immediacy
concept addressed by our humorous intervention is even more important in this learning mode),
and (ii) attrition rates among engineering students. Given that the unorthodox nature of our
approach will appeal to a demographic that does not usually consider engineering studies,
it has the potential to create a significant trend in engineering outreach and recruiting
to address the U.S. need for significant numbers of engineers in the near future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Numerous books and articles applaud the value of humor in the classroom to better engage students. After all, wasn’t learning supposed to be fun. Most people view technical material such as science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM)  as relatively dry and boring. As such, it is challenging to motivate students to study and work in these fields, despite the importance of training a sufficient number of scientists and engineers to meet the needs of our high-tech economy. If any area of study could benefit from humor to better engage students, it is the STEM fields. Unfortunately, most of the claims made in these books are based on personal observations and have not been extensively quantified. Nowhere is this more true than in the STEM fields. While many books on communication recommend the use of humor to better engage an audience, books on technical communication recommend against this (no wonder we’re bored in science and engineering classes).

We (a team including engineers, educators, a psychologist, and a stand-up comedian) studied the use of humor in several engineering classrooms to determine if humor can help address the challenge described above. We discovered a way to implement humor into engineering education that can effectively improve technical education. When the material is relatively simple, effective education is easy to achieve, but when it is difficult (as with many technical subjects) then humor can help learning. To maximize learning, we try to create a situation where most of your brainpower is used for transforming information and patterns into useful knowledge that we can store in our brains (learning). We want to avoid anything that creates distractions from the learning, and we found that sometimes humor can distract from learning in engineering classes. It did help engage students in the classroom, but it did not seem to directly help with learning. By studying how much brainpower was used for learning, and how much was used to deal with distractions, we found that blending the humor into the technical material was the most effective way to improve learning. This is not new, we just attempted to measure and describe it. This method is used by some airlines to get you to listen to the safety video at the beginning of the flight. They mix the funny situations into the safety warnings, rather than just telling jokes along with the announcement.

Mixing a relatable situation from everyday life with a technical idea or theory helps explain the concept because everyone can relate to it. Since the mixing of these two things is unexpected, a humorous reaction often results and better engages the students (humor is a bonus). Examples include applying advanced mathematical analysis to understanding how gummi-bears swell in water, how cookies get dry in a vending machine, and how many people will attend a party over time. This method allows anyone to create a humorous approach that can help learning without being a comedian. While this is important for STEM classes, its real impact is improved STEM education of the public. This approach should help us reach broader groups of people including populations that are underrepresented in the STEM fields. It has already been used successfully in various science and engineering festivals, as well as engineering classes.
